body_text.text: Roberto Chiesa, MD The first confirmed case of COVID-19 infection in Italy was reported in Lombardia region on 2 February 20, 2020, following the outbreak in Hubei Province in China, where in just 30 days it 3 spread from the city of Wuhan to the entire country (1). Aggressive policies allowed containment 4 of the epidemic in China, however by that time the WHO had declared a global pandemic. 5
body_text.section: Pattern of Vascular Disease in Lombardia (Italy) during the first month of the COVID-19 outbreak 1 2

body_text.text: The first cases in Italy were detected in a few small urban centers of Lombardia and the 6 Veneto regions and in spite of the immediate quarantine, the infection rapidly spread to other 7 regions in Italy. Still the largest number of COVID-19 cases were recorded in Lombardia, were the 8 epidemic has been particularly virulent and highly lethal. Lombardia has a high number of elderly 9 citizens, according to the 2019 report of the Italian Institute of Statistics (ISTAT) 13.7% of the 10 citizens are over 65 years of age and that for each 100 inhabitants < 14 years old there are 165,5 11 who are above age 65; a very high index of an aging population. Life expectancy in Lombardia 12 before the pandemic was 84 years , 3 years above the European life expectancy. have been made available in a matter of days at both publicly and privately-run centers. Clearly 8 many further logistics adjustments had to be made in order to optimize the resources to this 9 rapidly changing situation, moreover medical teaching also underwent radical changes. 10

body_text.text: Being one of the 4 Hubs selected by the local health authorities of Lombardia for vascular 11 surgical emergencies, our Institution is cooperating with 8 Spokes serving a population of 12 approximately 2.5M inhabitants. Several interesting patterns have emerged: during the initial 13 days, in fact, the number of non-elective admissions of subjects with vascular disease was lower 14 than usual, possibly due to a reluctance in the general population to seek assistance in a hospital 15

body_text.text: As we entered the second week, the number of vascular emergencies resumed, and there 17 was a clear increase in acute peripheral arterial occlusive disease; the tendency was towards older 18 patients (median age 75 years, range 50-96), with advanced ischemia and below knee thrombosis. 19

body_text.text: As of the third week a significant number of cases initially hospitalized for COVID-19 21 related pneumonia, both on and off artificial ventilators presented with peripheral ischemia of 22 both lower and occasionally upper limbs and required treatment. Interestingly, most of these 23 patients were already receiving antithrombotic prophylaxis. During Duplex ultrasonographic assessment of these patients the deep venous circulation was also studied showing an alarmingly 1 high number of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), with little or no additional specific symptoms. We 2 therefore screened for DVT 108 Covid-19 patients, the incidence was 23% for patients on 3 ventilators and 8% for patients off ventilators; particularly affected were the popliteal and calf patients' response to different anticoagulants, and to identify blood-circulating biomarkers as 12 predictors of thrombotic complications. 13
body_text.section: Pattern of Vascular Disease in Lombardia (Italy) during the first month of the COVID-19 outbreak 1 2

body_text.text: We are now well into our 5 th week of the COVID-19 emergency and we are dealing with the 14 new challenges in an increasingly efficient way. The supply chain poses some issues not only for 15 personal protective equipment (PPE) but also for seemingly trivial devices such as thrombectomy 16 catheters, peripheral vascular grafts, specific drugs etc. Centers that are treating vascular patients 17 in the times of the COVID-19 pandemic could face similar issues and could be better prepared. 18
body_text.section: Pattern of Vascular Disease in Lombardia (Italy) during the first month of the COVID-19 outbreak 1 2

body_text.text: Lastly, adequate protection and wise allocation of the human resources, including nurses, 19 doctors, assisting personnel is of paramount importance since the infection have not spared 20 healthcare workers. In Italy 116 physicians died from COVID-19 related disease since March 10, 2020. 22

FIGREF0.text: 13 As the virulence and lethality of the COVID-19 epidemic in Italy was unusually grave, both 14 the central and local authorities rapidly initiated measures of social distancing and on March 22, 15 2020 a lockdown was ordered for the entire country with only essential services still functioning. 16 These measures are still active as of April 15, 2020 when the number of new cases has reached a 17 plateau. These measures initially received skeptical comments from most of the other countries, 18 however in a matter of weeks most western countries followed in issuing similar drastic measures. 19 From an epidemiological point of view, many of these countries are reporting a similar pattern of 20 infection curves with 2-3 weeks delay over Italy. 21 The public health system of Lombardia, where publicly run and privately-run hospitals 22 coexist, has been struck very hard by the epidemic, especially in municipalities like Cremona Lodi 23 and Bergamo where the hospitals were rapidly overwhelmed. The regional healthcare authorities 24 decided to create e Hub/Spoke system for cardiovascular and surgical emergencies, where a small number of large centers (Hubs: IRCCS Ospedale San Raffaele Milano, Fondazione Poliambulanza 1 Brescia, Centro Cardiologico Monzino Milano, ASST Milanese Ospedale di Legnano) would serve 2 the whole region for non-elective cases, while greatly limiting the number of elective ones.
